title: Cyber Daily: China's Tougher Regulation Is the New Normal, Tencent President Says
text:
China's own internet companies have faced tighter control from the government in numerous areas including data, competition, education and online content, The Wall Street Journal reports. Alibaba Group Holding Ltd. was fined a record $2.8 billion in April for abusing its dominant position over rivals and merchants on e-commerce platforms, while ride-hailing giant Didi Global Inc. has been undergoing a monthslong cybersecurity review.

On Wednesday, Tencent Holdings Ltd., the world's largest videogame publisher, reported slower growth and profitability, in part because of Beijing's strict new rules for how much time youth can spend online.

Double Down on Protection Against Triple Threat Extortion

Cybercriminals have a new tactic: triple extortion. This debilitating combination of ransomware, the exposure of stolen data, and DDoS attacks is something all organizations need to prepare for.

Watch Video

Tencent President Martin Lau, speaking on a conference call Wednesday, said the company is working actively with Chinese regulators.

Chinese internet companies are seeking new growth drivers as their core businesses mature and come under closer regulatory scrutiny. Last week, Tencent introduced three self-designed semiconductors, including chips for artificial-intelligence computing and video processing, following in the footsteps of Alibaba and search engine operator Baidu Inc. that have also been developing their own chips.

The metaverse is enticing as well, Tencent said. The company's experience in games and social media—Tencent operates social media app WeChat—would allow it to approach metaverse opportunities through multiple pathways. Beijing would be supportive of development of such technologies so long as they follow the rules, Mr. Lau said.

More Cybersecurity and Privacy News

Swiss manufacturer Bucher shuts down operations in two divisions to stop cyberattack. Bucher Industries AG said on Wednesday in a brief notice on its website that its "monitoring systems reported activities indicating the preparation of an attack by external attackers." The Zurich-based machinery maker said it disabled the tech infrastructure of the Bucher Municipal unit globally, which also affected the Switzerland facilities of its Bucher Specials unit. The company said it is working with unnamed external experts to investigate so that technology systems can be restored as soon as possible.

Jen Easterly, director of the Cybersecurity and Infrastructure Security Agency, worries about misinformation, as a professional and as a parent. "One could argue we're in the business of critical infrastructure," she tells Wired, "and the most critical infrastructure is our cognitive infrastructure." Exploits and Fixes

New patches for Microsoft's Exchange email software should be applied "immediately," the company said. The fixes are for the on-premises version of the email system; cloud-based Exchange users are already covered, Microsoft said in a blog post. (ZDNet)

Malware targets Android users of Instagram, Netflix and Twitter. The so-called MasterFred hacking tool creates false login screens to steal financial details. (Bleeping Computer)

Share this email with a friend.

Comic book supply-chain delays: Tech systems are down and shipments are delayed in some cases for two to four days at Diamond Comic Distributors Inc. after a ransomware attack on Sunday. As it deals with the incident, the company has switched email systems to continue to communicate with customers. Comic book shipments have been interrupted in U.S. cities and internationally, Diamond said. (ZDNet)

"We want to assure you that customer data and financial information is not stored on our network and as such we have no reason to believe it has been impacted by this attack," the company said in one of many updates it has posted online this week.

175,000

Number of computers world-wide infected with REvil ransomware to date, according to the U.S. Attorney General Merrick Garland. At least $200 million has been paid in ransom to hacking groups using REvil malware, he said.
